data.title: L'Estaque, c. 1910
data.medium: Oil on canvas; 57.3 x 73.7 cm (22 1/2 x 29 in.)
data.collection: Arthur Jerome Eddy Memorial Collection, gift of Elizabeth Day McCormick, 1931.518
data.description: Emilie Charmy was a self-taught painter who exhibited with the Fauves. Here she employed her vividly colored Fauvist palette and rapid brushwork to depict a view of L’Estaque, the small French fishing village made famous by the landscapes of Paul Cézanne and later Georges Braque. Modern art dealer Emile Druet lent three paintings by Charmy to the Chicago presentation, where they hung in the French gallery alongside works by Henri Matisse.
data.citation: Emilie Charmy (French, 1878–1974), L’Estaque, c. 1910. Oil on canvas. 22 1/2 x 29 in. (57.3 x 73.7 cm). The Art Institute of Chicago. Arthur Jerome Eddy Memorial Collection, gift of Elizabeth Day McCormick, 1931.518.
